Graphical abstract A schematic of our three-procedure Infoad protocol which accelerates the discovery and promotes the understanding of anchoring materials in Li-S batteries. Lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries are notable for their high theoretical energy density, but the ‘shuttle effect’ and the limited conversion kinetics of Li-S species can downgrade their actual performance. An essential strategy is to design anchoring materials (AMs) to appropriately adsorb Li-S species. Herein, we propose a new three-procedure protocol, named InfoAd (Informative Adsorption) to evaluate the anchoring of Li2S on two-dimensional (2D) materials and disclose the underlying importance of material features by combining high-throughput calculation workflow and machine learning (ML). In this paradigm, we calculate the anchoring of Li2S on 1255 2D A x B y (B in the VIA/VIIA group) materials and pick out 44 (un)reported nontoxic 2D binary A x B y AMs, in which the importance of the geometric features on the anchoring effect is revealed by ML for the first time. We develop a new Infograph model for crystals to accurately predict whether a material has a moderate binding with Li2S and extend it to all 2D materials. Our InfoAd protocol elucidates the underlying structure–property relationship of Li2S adsorption on 2D materials and provides a general research framework of adsorption-related materials for catalysis and energy/substance storage. Keywords Adsorption Anchoring material Li-S battery Extreme gradient boosting Graph neural network Material geometry Semi-supervised learning 1 Introduction With the demand for high-energy–density storage devices, lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries have received wide attention due to the high theoretical capacity (1672 mAh/g) of the sulfur cathode, which is more than 6 times that of the popular lithium cobalt oxide (274 mAh/g) in Li-ion batteries [1–11]. Despite its prospective potential, the retained cathode capacities of most experimental Li-S batteries remain at approximately 1000 mAh/g. It is reported that the unrestricted migration of Li-S species (shuttle effect) and the limited conversion kinetics of Li-S species are two main challenges for performance attenuation [4,5,7,8,12–16]. Anchoring materials (AMs) play a basic role in relieving these issues, as they can inhibit the shuttle effect [17–24] and tune the catalytic conversion of Li-S species [25,26] by adsorption interactions. To date, two-dimensional (2D) metal compounds are emerging AMs owing to their great polarity, high specific surface area, and good ionic transport ability [27–32]. Zhang et al. investigated 9 kinds of 2D metal compounds and gave a simple picture of the anchoring strength for Li-S species: graphene ≈ chloride < sulfide < oxide [33]. In comparison, there are still many unexplored domains in the chemical space of 2D compound materials. In recent years, machine learning (ML) has successfully accelerated the design of novel AMs and has revealed the underlying mechanisms for metal-ion batteries [34–41]. For example, Li et al. trained an extreme gradient boosting (XGBoost) model [42] to quickly screen 14 appropriate AMs from 342 AB2 monolayers [43]. Their ML model also identified the covalent radius of B with a negative valence as one of the most important features for the anchoring strength of Li-S species. Furthermore, graph neural networks (GNNs) have more natural compatibility with chemical insights and can distinguish polymorphs [44–46]. An important application of GNN models is to provide a potential energy surface (PES) for fast prediction of energies, which successfully enables the simulation of lengthy ion transportation in solid electrolytes [47]. Li et al. first utilized a GNN PES to evaluate the binding energies of adsorbed Li-S species configurations and predicted MoSe2 as a better AM than WSe2 [48]. Lian et al. trained a CGCNN model [49] to efficiently predict the optimal binding energies between Li-S species and metal-doped graphene-based materials. They found that the Ti-, V-, Zr-, Nb-, Mo-, Ta-, and W-doped ones have sufficient anchoring strengths [50]. All the ML models are sufficiently accurate in analyzing specific materials, but the universality of the previous works is still very limited in general. In this work, we propose a material analysis protocol (Infoad, Informative adsorption) to efficiently screen out 2D materials with appropriate adsorption strength and provide a microscopic understanding of the influence of material features. We build a dataset including the binding energies of Li2S on 1255 kinds of 2D A x B y (B in the VIA/VIIA group) with an automatic DFT workflow. Then, we construct an interpretable XGBoost model to identify the importance of 77 intrinsic material features. At last, we develop a crystal Infograph (C-Infograph) model to classify specific anchoring materials according to the binding energies. Based on this paradigm, we report 44 kinds of nontoxic 2D A x B y AM candidates and systematically reveal the importance of the geometric features in anchoring Li2S by ML for the first time. Besides, we also extend our ML model to all 2D materials. Considering that the binding energy is a basic descriptor of adsorption-related behaviors, we believe our workflow is helpful for the discovery of adsorbent materials for substance/energy storage and catalytic reactions. 2 Methodology 2.1 Protocol framework Fig. 1 briefly demonstrates three procedures of our proposed protocol. (1) Procedure 1: Database construction Initially, all 2D materials are extracted from the C2DB [51,52] and 2D matpedia [53] databases. The duplicated structures are removed based on the structure matcher in pymatgen (PMG) [54]. Only the C2DB data annotated with ‘high thermodynamic stability’ and ‘high dynamical stability (phonons/stiffness)’ [51], as well as 2Dmatpedia data with decomposition energy < 0.1 eV/atom are confirmed as the data of stable materials [53]. Since binary 2D materials are the compounds with the simplest elemental component, the stable 2D A x B y (B in the VIA/VIIA group) monolayers are chosen as our research objects. Subsequently, we just directly investigate the adsorption of Li2S on the basal plane (001) of them and adopt an automatic DFT workflow to evaluate their binding energies ( E a ) for Li2S in a high-throughput way. We find that the E a of Li2S is an efficient indicator for describing the adsorption of Li-S species, since Li2S not only saves the calculation cost but also has the same adsorption trend with other Li-S species according to the work of Zhang [33], Mukherjee [55], Ji [56], and Sun [57] et al. Then, we construct classification labels, instead of regression labels, for evaluating E a by ML models. The classification models are more robust since there are perturbation errors from the approximation of exchange–correlation functional [58] and from the unconsidered experimental effects that are discussed in Section 3.4. Here, once 0 eV < E a < 4.00 eV, the corresponding material is labeled with ‘1′ (moderate anchoring, positive sample); otherwise, the label is ‘0′ (too strong/weak anchoring, negative sample). (2) Procedure 2: Feature importance analysis Then, 77 intrinsic features of A x B y are chosen for the input descriptors. The detailed meanings of these features are given in SI-1 (Supplementary information, SI). Generally, these features can be divided into 4 groups: 2 of them are only related to elements A or B, and each group consists of 34 features. They are intrinsic atomic properties (atomic number, van der Waals radius, electronegativity…) and the properties of the corresponding simple substance with the most abundance (melting point…) [59]. Another group involves 3 features concerned with both A and B, including the stoichiometric ratio and 2 principal components of many-body-tensor-representation (MBTR) (mbtrk1_1 and mbtrk1_2) [60]. The last group contains 6 geometric features of A x B y , including space group number, 3 average values of bond lengths/angles and dihedral angles, as well as 2 principal components of MBTR derived from bond lengths/angles (mbtrk2 and mbtrk3). Fig. S1 further visualizes the proportions of 4 types of features in the input vector descriptor. With the input vector descriptors and the labels, an XGBoost model is trained to compare the importance scores of various elemental and geometric features. (3) Procedure 3: Classification As shown in Fig. 2 , we develop a crystal Infograph (C-Infograph) algorithm to classify whether a 2D material belongs to category ‘1′ or ‘0′, corresponding to a positive or negative material for anchoring Li2S species, respectively. As the original Infograph was only applied for molecules before [61], we convert a crystal structure to an input crystal graph G for Infograph under the guidance of the CGCNN scheme, in which the nodes represent the crystal sites and the edges linking nodes depict adjacent relations between sites. C-Infograph is a GNN algorithm that supports 2 special technologies: infomax and semi-supervised learning [62–74]. Infomax aims to maximize the average mutual information (MI, I Ψ ) [75] between the local features of crystal site u ( h φ u G ) and the global features ( H φ G ) of the entire crystal graph in dataset G . (1) I ¯ g - l ( G ) = ∑ G ∈ G 1 G ∑ u ∈ G I Ψ h φ u G ; H φ G where φ and Ψ are the trainable graph convolution blocks (encoder) and discriminator, respectively. Both h φ u G and H φ G are output from φ . Meanwhile, G is the node number of G . With a φ containing K blocks, h φ u G includes the features about 0 to K-th neighbors of site u (Fig. S2). Thus, Eq. (1) reflects the correlation between the local and global features, and infomax encourages the model to learn the local–global relations of material geometries. Meanwhile, C-Infograph integrates MI into the combined loss function ( L t o t a l ), which is minimized in semi-supervised training and indirectly realizes infomax. (2) L t o t a l = L s u p e r v i s e d y Φ G L , o G L - L u n s u p e r v i s e d G , G = G L ∪ G U (3) L u n s u p e r v i s e d G = I ¯ g - l G + λ I ¯ g - g G (4) I ¯ g - g ( G ) = ∑ G ∈ G 1 G I Ψ H Φ G ; H φ G L s u p e r v i s e d is the loss function of the supervised GNNs, such as the original CGCNN, ALIGNN [76], and geo-CGNN [77], reflecting the error of the prediction ( y Φ ) by referring to the labels ( o ) of the sub-dataset evaluated by DFT ( G L ). Negative log-likelihood [78] is used as L s u p e r v i s e d in our classification. The unsupervised loss ( L u n s u p e r v i s e d ) consists of two terms and its first term is the aforementioned MI (Eq. (1)). Since the calculation of L u n s u p e r v i s e d has nothing to do with the labels ( o ), it allows us to utilize the unlabeled sub-dataset ( G U ) that is not evaluated by density functional theory (DFT) in training. Here, Φ and φ are two different encoders, and thus they output different global features ( H Φ G and H φ G ) of G . Φ participates in the supervised task requiring y Φ and o , while φ is just used for the unsupervised task of calculating the variables ( h φ u G and H φ G ) that are unrelated to o . In order to transfer the useful knowledge about the unsupervised task to the supervised task, the second term of L u n s u p e r v i s e d also maximums the average mutual information between H Φ G and H φ G (Eq. (4)) in training. In addition, the coefficient λ in (Eq. (3)) should be a positive constant. 2.2 Density functional theory calculations All DFT calculations are carried out by the Vienna ab initio simulation package (VASP) [79–81]. The formalism of the generalized gradient approximation proposed by Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (GGA-PBE [82]) is adopted to describe the electronic exchange–correlation part, and the utilized plane waves are constructed by the projector augmented wave (PAW) method with a cutoff of 520 eV. Additionally, the Grimme D3 correction method with Becke-Johnson damping [83] is introduced to capture the significant van der Waals effect. With a Γ-centered K-point mesh sampling of 40 Å−3 in reciprocal space, the convergence criteria of electronic and ionic relaxation are set to 10−5 eV and 0.05 eV/Å, respectively. Collinear spin polarization is considered in the optimization of structures, and the initial magnetic moments are given by PMG. Additionally, considering the periodic effect, the image distances are guaranteed to exceed 13 Å in all supercells. PMG is also used to generate the initial adsorption structures by searching all the possible adsorption sites on the material surface. To reduce the calculation cost, only the adsorbate is firstly relaxed to find the energy-optimal configuration. Then, all the atomistic positions of the optimal initial structure are fully relaxed to evaluate the optimal binding energies ( E a ) by (5) E a = E s u b + E a d - E s u b + a d where E s u b , E a d , and E s u b + a d are the total energies of the fully relaxed pristine adsorbent, free adsorbate, and adsorption system, respectively. Meanwhile, the displacement ( D ) of the adsorbent atoms, or the atomic position R difference before and after adsorption, is calculated by (6) D = ‖ R a f t e r - R b e f o r e ‖ (7) D m = max D where D m is a direct indicator of structure distortion. According to Ulissi et al.’s definition, once D m is larger than 1.50 Å, it is considered an unstable structure [84]. 2.3 Performance indicator for ML For classification models, the receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curve is a commonly used performance indicator [85] to compare the true positive rate (TPR) and false positive rate (FPR). The larger the (integral) area under the ROC curve (ROC AUC), the better the overall classification performance. The upper limit of the ROC AUC is 1, and a model with a ROC AUC ≤ 0.5 is useless, as the ROC AUC of random guessing is 0.5. According to the number of the positive/negative samples which are truly/falsely recognized by a model, we have (8) TPR = TP TP + F N (9) FPR = FP FP + T N where TP/FP is the number of true/false positive samples, respectively, while TN/FN is the number of true/false negative samples, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 High-throughput DFT database construction In total, there are 3134 unique and stable materials in the C2DB [51,52] and 2DMatPedia [53]. With a high-throughput DFT workflow, 1255 stable A x B y monolayers (B in the VIA/VIIA group) with E a of −5–10 eV are exploited as the labeled data for ML training. It is noted that our database covers geometric diversities far beyond the work of Li [43] and Lian [50] et al. Based on kernel density estimation, Fig. 3 shows the statistical Gaussian distributions of E a for these 1255 2D A x B y materials. For A in the main (or transition) group, the order of E a follows alkali(ne) (or early transition) compounds < early p block (or late transition) compounds. For B in the VIA/VIIA group, the order follows tellurides ≈ selenides ≈ sulfides < oxides and iodides < bromides < chlorides < fluorides, which is consistent with the work of Zhang et al. [33] . These statistics provide more understanding of the component regulation of AMs and verify the prior knowledge, since they can be generally explained with the hard-soft-acid-base (HSAB) theory [86]. In Li2S, S2− is a soft Lewis base and tends to bind softer A cation, while Li+ is a hard Lewis acid and tends to bind with harder B anion. Meanwhile, this theory indicates that a higher softness (lower hardness) essentially corresponds to a greater covalent binding ability and a weaker electrostatic binding capability [87]. For A cation, because of the more valence electrons of the corresponding elements, early p block (or late transition) cations are generally softer than alkali(ne) (or early transition) cations, as they are more likely to remain valence electrons for forming covalent bonds. For B anion in the same group, as the period number increases, the radius becomes larger and larger, which makes the charge distribution not concentrated enough and thus softens B anion. Based on multiple quantitative criteria (0 eV< E a < 4.00 eV, D m <1.50 Å, bandgap < 0.03 eV, and nontoxic), 242 A x B y monolayers are picked out and 44 kinds of materials among them are chosen as AM candidates (SI-2), since their physicochemical properties are similar to the superior AM (VS2, P 3 ¯ m 1 , E a =3.32 eV) reported by Cui et al.’s control experiment [88]. Ordered by the D m , the structures of the 5 promising stable candidates are shown in Fig. S3 and their detailed information is listed in Table 1 . It is also noteworthy that 6 A x B y materials (VSe2 [91], FeS [88], VS2 [17], VSe2 [91], NbSe2 [92], NiTe2 [90]) have been experimentally used as AMs, which exemplifies the effectiveness of E a for measuring anchoring strength. In the remaining 2D A x B y AM candidates, some monolayers have been prepared experimentally, such as TaS2 [89] and HfTe3 [93]. The other unreported monolayers may also be synthesized by imitating the preparation of the prototype materials. For example, the TiTe2 monolayer is likely to be obtained by the physical/chemical vapor deposition with a bulk precursor, which is similar to the preparation of CdI2 monolayer [94–96]. 3.2 Feature importance analysis After labeling 1255 materials with label 0/1 according to their binding energies, we train an XGBoost model (see its hyperparameters in Table S1) to analyze which material features are crucial for the anchoring effects. Fig. 4 (a) shows the top 10 influential factors of anchoring Li2S on 2D A x B y (B in the VIA/VIIA group). In descending order by feature importance, the top 6 are the average B-A-A-B dihedral angle (f0, A-A is the central axis), average B-A-B bond angle (f1, A site is the vertex), average A-B bond length (f2), mbtrk2 (f3), mbtrk3 (f4), and space group number (f5). Different from Li et al.’s work [53], we identify the geometric features (f0–f5), instead of the elemental features (f6– f9), as the most important features. Therefore, the Li2S anchoring on A x B y monolayers is very sensitive to their material geometries and capturing 2/3/4-body geometries (Fig. S4) may be the key to high-performance ML models. The Pearson correlation coefficients among these top 10 features are also visualized in Fig. 4(b). The strong correlations among the 2 MBTR features (f3, f4) probably originate from their mathematical definitions [60]. In contrast, the other 8 features are almost independent of each other, which means that they may constitute the minimum set of the necessary information for analyzing the anchoring effect. To further emphasize the geometric effects, we concretely analyze the Li2S adsorptions on 4 pairs of 2D A x B y polymorphs (CrO2, VS2, MnCl2, and GeO2), and each pair involves 2 space groups ( P 3 ¯ m 1 vs. P 4 ¯ m 2 / P 6 ¯ m 2 ). Fig. 5 and Table 2 show their E a (unit: eV) vs. charge density difference and necessary geometric feature values, respectively. For the MnCl2/GeO2 polymorphs, the charge density difference shows the “chemical effect” of geometric configurations [43]. Owing to the smaller coordination number of cations, the MnCl2/GeO2 ( P 4 ¯ m 2 , coordination = 4) structure provides a fairly larger E a (3.84/4.07 eV vs. 1.02/1.55 eV) by forming more bonds with S2− in Li2S than its polymorph ( P 3 ¯ m 1 , coordination = 6). Note that f2 of MnCl2/GeO2 ( P 4 ¯ m 2 , coordination = 4) is 0.170/0.139 smaller than that of its polymorph ( P 3 ¯ m 1 , coordination = 6), while the difference in f2 between CrO2/VS2 ( P 3 ¯ m 1 , coordination = 6) and its polymorph ( P 6 ¯ m 2 , coordination = 6) is smaller than 0.050. This agrees with the Goldschmidt-Pauling contraction [97–101] that a significantly smaller bond length usually induces a smaller coordination number for polymorphs. Therefore, f2 becomes a significant geometric feature. Meanwhile, the material geometries also induce the “physical effect”, which can be observed from the CrO2/VS2 polymorphs, as there is no obvious charge transfer between Li2S and the bottom B atoms. The interactions between Li+ and the bottom B atoms in CrO2/VS2 ( P 3 ¯ m 1 , E a =4.15/3.32 eV) are less shielded by the top atoms than its polymorph ( P 6 ¯ m 2 , E a =2.85/2.66 eV) because they are not right below the top atoms (Fig. S5). The contribution of the “physical effect” to E a should be fewer than the “chemical effect”, since the E a of MnCl2/GeO2 ( P 4 ¯ m 2 ) is 2.82/2.52 eV larger than that of its polymorph ( P 3 ¯ m 1 ), while the E a of CrO2/VS2 ( P 3 ¯ m 1 ) is just 1.30/0.56 eV greater than that of the corresponding polymorph ( P 6 ¯ m 2 ). Besides, f0 and f1 are also significant geometric features, as the difference between P 6 ¯ m 2 and P 3 ¯ m 1 is successfully identified by them. f0 and f1 of CrO2/VS2 ( P 6 ¯ m 2 ) are approximately 95.000 and 103.000, respectively, while those of the corresponding polymorphs ( P 3 ¯ m 1 ) are 102.857 and 108.000, respectively. Fig. 6 schematically shows the scoring procedures of the anchoring strength by our trained XGBoost model. Since the atomic radii (unit: pm) of V, Cr, Mn, and Ge belong to 4 intervals (>170, 165 to 170, 160 to 165, and < 160) in descending order, the scores on them by the model are 1, 0, −1, and −2, respectively. Similarly, the rating scores of O and S/Cl are 2 and 1, respectively, as their radii belong to 2 intervals (<75 and >75). [102] As a result, the summations of the 2 kinds of scores reflect the 2 intervals (>2 and <2) for E a of the 4 isomorphic P 3 ¯ m 1 structures, but they still cannot tell one polymorph ( P 4 ¯ m 2 / P 6 ¯ m 2 ) from another ( P 3 ¯ m 1 ) in a pair. According to the above space group contribution, the model further gives geometric scores of 3, 1, and 0 to P 4 ¯ m 2 , P 3 ¯ m 1 , and P 6 ¯ m 2 , respectively. Summing up the elemental and geometric scores, the total scores of 1, 2, and 3 are finally obtained. They correspond to 3 intervals of E a (<2, 2 to 3, and >3) and successfully capture the difference between the polymorphs in a pair. 3.3 Adsorption classification by C-Infograph In this part, we compare the classification performances between C-Infograph and 3 other GNNs (CGCNN, ALIGNN, Geo-CGNN) by adopting the 10-fold stratified cross-validation (CV) for 5 times (Hyperparameters of these 4 GNN models are given in Tables S2–S6) In each CV, the labeled data are split into 10 folds of the same size. 9 of them are selected for training, and the remaining one is used as the test set. Fig. 7 and Table S7 suggest the average performances of these 4 models. The average ROC AUCs are all above 0.900 on the training set, while only that of the C-Infograph is over 0.800 on the test set. Although all 4 models can perfectly fit the training set, C-Infograph outperforms the other 3 GNNs in generalization performance with a ROC AUC of 0.941/0.810 on the training/test set, as its ROC AUC difference on the 2 datasets (0.131) is smaller than that of the others, which reflects its better robustness. The advantages of our C-Infograph on the classification of Li2S adsorption are attributed to the infomax and semi-supervised learning for limited labeled data. On the one hand, traditional GNNs only learn the relation between the global structure and objective property to make predictions, whereas C-Infograph additionally learns the relation among different levels of geometries to improve the prediction. On the other hand, semi-supervised learning captures extra insights from the distribution of unlabeled data, which corrects the biased insights from the labeled data and better avoids overfitting. Finally, the trained C-Infograph model is used to evaluate E a for all the uncalculated stable 2D monolayers from C2DB/2DMatPedia and predict that 372 of them meet the screening criteria (0 eV< E a < 4.00 eV, bandgap < 0.03 eV, and nontoxic), which may indicate that the 2D AMs that have been reported indeed only consist of the tip of the iceberg. As a result, the application of 2D AMs still has very great potential. 3.4 Limitations and prospects Our work provides a preliminary screening of 2D materials for anchoring Li2S and targeted guidance for further experimental confirmation, however, we note that our simplified model ignores some potential influence factors in the actual working condition, such as the solvent effects and the stacking configurations. Although these two factors bring additional interactions, our preliminary calculations show their effects on the change of E a are smaller than 0.80 eV for the example materials (Tables S8, S9). Hence, these two effects may be treated as perturbations and have weaker influences on our classification models than the regression models. By comparison, different exposed crystalline surfaces may more obviously change E a , but our work is still meaningful since this factor can be neglected when using well-separated monolayer AMs [103–105]. Meanwhile, our work only focuses on the binding energies of Li2S while the diffusion behavior is also key for Li-S conversion. Hopefully, it was reported that the diffusion barrier of Li2S is decisive and there may be scaling relations between the diffusion barriers and the binding energies of Li-S species [106], and thus there should be considerable AMs that are screened by our work possessing appropriate diffusion performances. Our conclusions have nice consistency with the past researches and basic theories, [17,33,55–57,86–88,90–92] which indicates that E a of Li2S may be a good indicator for describing the anchoring strength of Li-S species. Apart from constructing a classification model for qualitatively predicting AMs, our protocol can also be used for building up a regression model that quantitatively predicts the binding energy values (Fig. S6) [107] and both models can preliminarily narrow the search range of AMs in the expensive DFT or experimental investigations to some extent. Besides, we find that no matter which objective (regression or classification with different criteria) is chosen for ML, our protocol gets the same main conclusion that the geometric features are significant in designing the AMs for Li2S (Fig. S7), which reflects the flexibility of our protocol at least. Since the sodium-sulfur (Na-S) and aluminum-sulfur (Al-S) batteries also suffer from the shuttle effect of Na-S and Al-S species [108,109], it is also promising to promote our protocol to these batteries. 4 Conclusions In summary, we introduce Infoad, a protocol based on high-throughput DFT calculations and ML, to build a universal structure–property relationship for the adsorption strength of Li2S on 2D binary materials. As a proof-of-concept, our protocol not only validates the previous experience, but also brings 3 new achievements. (1) 44 kinds of AM candidates are screened out of 1255 2D A x B y (B in the VIA/VIIA group) materials, and they exhibit stability as well as the potential to improve Li-S batteries at the same time. (2) Our XGBoost model first systematically unveils the strong correlation between geometric features and the anchoring effects of Li2S. (3) Our novel C-Infograph excels typical GNNs (CGCNN, ALIGNN, Geo-CGNN) in classifying materials with different anchoring strengths and proclaims the great potential of 2D AMs, as 372 uncalculated monolayers are predicted as potential AMs. These exemplary achievements provide fundamental power for producing more and better Li-S batteries, as well as proving the utility of our Infoad in sophisticated adsorption studies. We hope to promote Infoad to catalysis/energy storage materials and arouse more attention to material geometries and unlabeled data in the future. coredata.dc:description: Lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries are notable for their high theoretical energy density, but the ‘shuttle effect’ and the limited conversion kinetics of Li-S species can downgrade their actual performance. An essential strategy is to design anchoring materials (AMs) to appropriately adsorb Li-S species. Herein, we propose a new three-procedure protocol, named InfoAd (Informative Adsorption) to evaluate the anchoring of Li2S on two-dimensional (2D) materials and disclose the underlying importance of material features by combining high-throughput calculation workflow and machine learning (ML). In this paradigm, we calculate the anchoring of Li2S on 1255 2D A x B y (B in the VIA/VIIA group) materials and pick out 44 (un)reported nontoxic 2D binary A x B y AMs, in which the importance of the geometric features on the anchoring effect is revealed by ML for the first time. We develop a new Infograph model for crystals to accurately predict whether a material has a moderate binding with Li2S and extend it to all 2D materials. Our InfoAd protocol elucidates the underlying structure–property relationship of Li2S adsorption on 2D materials and provides a general research framework of adsorption-related materials for catalysis and energy/substance storage.

coredata.dc:title: Unfolding the structure-property relationships of Li2S anchoring on two-dimensional materials with high-throughput calculations and machine learning
